docs.lead_paragraph: The 223rd session of the New York State Legislature roared to a close Friday, with a head-spinning succession of deals on major issues that made this the most productive session in recent memory. The Senate, the Assembly and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed on a far-reaching package of gun controls, a major overhaul of the state's sexual assault laws and a law providing heavier penalties for hate crimes. On the final day of the session, they reached agreement on a law allowing patients to look up doctors' malpractice histories, a few days after striking a deal on a law requiring parental notification when pesticides are used in schools, and possible neighborhood notification when they are used on lawns.

headline.main: Summary of Major Actions of the Legislature's 223rd Session

docs.lead_paragraph: Bridget Claire Kule, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher A. Kule of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Brandon Wilson Lower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Lower II of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. Jay Sidebotham performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan. Mrs. Lower, 25, was until April a design assistant at Branca Inc., an interior design business in Chicago. She graduated from Yale University and studied at the Harrington Institute of Interior Design. Her father is a lawyer in Manhattan. Her mother, Mary Jo Kule, is a social worker at the Cobble Hill Health Center in Brooklyn.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the pattern here was as reliable as sunrise. Democrats and Republicans went at each other hammer and tongs, hurling verbal bombs, delaying budgets for months, barely speaking to each other and tying unrelated issues together until most of them collapsed in recriminations. Not this year. The legislative session that wound to a close Friday had its bloody episodes, but they were Republican against Republican and Democrat against Democrat, with remarkably little partisan carping. And it ended with an extraordinary number of agreements on big issues, making it not only the most amicable but by far the most productive session since well before George E. Pataki became governor five and a half years ago.

headline.main: Agreements, Not Discord, Mark Close In Albany

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton announced a major change in his proposal for Medicare drug benefits today, making it much more generous to millions of elderly people and much more costly to the federal government. The new proposal came four days before the House of Representatives is scheduled to vote on a Republican proposal to offer drug benefits, through private insurance companies, to all 39 million people on Medicare.

headline.main: CLINTON PROPOSING MUCH LARGER PLAN FOR DRUG BENEFITS

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton announces major change in his proposal for Medicare drug benefits, making it much more generous to millions of elderly people and much more costly to federal government; House of Representatives is scheduled to vote on Republican proposal to offer drug benefits, through private insurance companies, to all 39 million people on Medicare; Clinton says his revised proposal would cost $79 billion over five years, almost twice the cost of Republicans' proposal; Clinton says Republican plan is not a Medicare benefit, but a private insurance program which many seniors will not be able to afford (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton announced a major change in his proposal for Medicare drug benefits today, making it much more generous to millions of elderly people and much more costly to the federal government.    The new proposal came four days before the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical Assurance Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Professionals Group Inc. for $232 million plus debt, creating the nation's third-largest medical malpractice insurance provider. Professionals Group stockholders will receive $12 cash and $14 in stock of the new holding company or $26 in cash for each of their shares, a 62.5 percent premium over Thursday's closing price. Medical Assurance shareholders will exchange their shares one-for-one. Stock in Professionals Group, which is based in Okemos, Mich., jumped $6.859, to $22.859. Medical Assurance is based in Birmingham, Ala.

headline.main: MEDICAL ASSURANCE IS SET TO ADD PROFESSIONALS GROUP

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A June 17 news article reports that hospitals are ''reeling from federal spending cuts.'' I would take this further to say that academic medicine is in a perilous state. The United States has the finest combination of medical research, education and quality care, and advances in these areas are among the greatest accomplishments of the last century. But we need to strengthen public policy in terms of giving dedicated financial support to hospitals and medical schools.
docs.abstract: Letter from Herbert Pardes, president and chief executive of New York-Presbyterian Healthcare System, commenting on June 17 article on plight of teaching hospitals, says US needs universal health care coverage to help both indigent people and the institutions that serve them; says teaching hospitals are central to maintaining the best American medicine

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Legislature voted yesterday to notify the public about malpractice judgments and disciplinary actions against doctors practicing in New York State. The information would be posted on the Internet and available through a toll-free telephone number. The measure, which Gov. George E. Pataki said he was studying, would put New York among a handful of states that give consumers extensive information about the practice histories of doctors and the quality of hospitals. The state already provides a Web site listing the names of doctors it has taken disciplinary action against, but it contains much less information than the new law would require. Also, few New Yorkers know about the site, health care policy experts say.

headline.main: Legislators Approve Web List Disclosing Missteps by Doctors

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature votes to notify public about malpractice judgments against doctors; information would be posted on Internet and available through toll-free telephone number; measure puts New York among handful of states that give consumers extensive information about practice histories of doctors and quality of hospitals; will require Department of Health to post on Web site everything from mundane to damning malpractice history and hospital dismissals that stem from harm to patients; will also require health commissioner to develop notice to be posted on hospital and doctors' offices alerting patients to site, and to 800 number; is being studied by Gov George E Pataki (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Genesis Health Ventures Inc., which operates skilled nursing and assisted-living centers, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. The company -- with about 34,000 employees, $1.86 billion in 1999 revenue and more than $2 billion in debt -- is seeking approval of a federal bankruptcy judge in Wilmington for $250 million in loans to continue operations while it reworks its finances.

headline.main: Genesis Health Ventures Fils for Bankruptcy

docs.abstract: Genesis Health Ventures Inc files for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Bankruptcy Code; shares of Genesis are suspended on New York Stock Exchange, where they will be delisted; Genesis says it is faced with huge cuts in Medicare reimbursements; 197 units of skilled managed care provider Multicare Companies--about 43 percent owned by Genesis--file Chapter 11 petitions in Delaware (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a major test case, a federal appeals court has upheld a Texas law allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations in state court for medical malpractice. But the judges struck down a part of the law that gave patients the right to an independent review of H.M.O. decisions denying benefits or coverage.

headline.main: In a Test Case on H.M.O.'s, Patients Both Win and Lose

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court, in a major test case, upholds Texas law allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations in state court for medical malpractice but strikes down part of law giving patients right to independent review of HMO decisions denying benefits or coverage; plaintiffs in case, all units of Aetna Inc, applaud decision; consumer advocates say ruling demonstrates need for Congress to define patients' rights (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: MORE PARK ARRESTS Five more suspects in the Central Park attacks were arrested yesterday, bringing to 25 the number accused of sexually abusing women after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade on June 11. One man, Aerial Boxill, 28, of New Haven, surrendered to detectives, while Darrell Jamison, 18, of Queens and Abel Ortiz, 23, of the Bronx were apprehended by detectives. All three were charged with one count of sexual abuse and one count of riot. Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman, said that two others, Juan Miranda, 22, of Paterson, N.J., and Felix Collazo, 22, of the Lower East Side, were charged with sexual abuse. The Police Department is still seeking 17 suspects. C.J. Chivers (NYT)
